DOCNAME: ALLIANZ-SLOVENSKA POISTOVNA, A.S., AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Ján Šikuta;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicants are the following CARDINAL private insurance companies which were established under the laws of GPE in DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and have their registered seats in GPE ( GPE ) : ORG – Slovenská poisťovňa , a.s . ; Česká poisťovňa - ORG , akciová spoločnosť ; ČSOB GPE , a.s . ; ORG poisťovňa , a.s . ORG ; ORG poisťovňa , a. s. and ORG poisťovňa , a.s .
The applicant companies were represented before the ORG by Mr Ľ. Fogaš , a lawyer practising in GPE .
ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by PERSON , their Agent , and PERSON , Co - Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE Act no . PERSON . on Insurance ( “ the LAW ” ) came into force . The LAW set an obligation for insurance companies doing business in the field of compulsory contractual insurance of liability for damage caused by the operation of motor vehicles to pay , on a DATE basis , PERCENT of the premiums collected DATE to ORG ( “ the Ministry ” ) . ORG would pass on those funds to certain bodies responsible for saving and protecting lives and property in road accidents such as fire brigades , rescue services and emergency hotlines .

On DATE the applicant companies , who do business in the above - mentioned field , lodged an action against the Ministry with the Bratislava I ORG ( ORG súd ) . They requested that the ORG rule that they were not obliged to pay PERCENT of the premiums they collected as stipulated by LAW . In their view the LAW violated their property rights and the nondiscrimination principle guaranteed by LAW and the Convention .

On DATE ORG terminated the proceedings and stated that there was no other ORG organ to which the case could be transferred . It held that the relation between the parties was of a public - law nature and could not be considered civil or commercial , in which case it would be covered by the area of private law and the ordinary courts would have jurisdiction to examine it on the basis of LAW . No dispute over private - law matters was found to exist .

On DATE ORG ( PERSON súd ) upheld the decision of ORG following an appeal by the applicant companies . The view was expressed that the specific obligation had been imposed upon the applicants by legislation and no legal provision permitted ordinary courts to rule on the alleged non - conformity of legislation with LAW . That was a matter solely for ORG ( Ústavný súd ) to examine in the context of a motion lodged under LAW by one of various specified State organs .

The applicants then claimed before ORG , in a complaint under LAW , that they were not obliged to pay the above - mentioned contributions as the obligation had been imposed on them unconstitutionally . They further complained that the courts had refused to determine their claim .

On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible for the applicant companies’ failure to exhaust ordinary remedies , in view of which ORG lacked jurisdiction to consider the complaint . In particular , ORG found that the applicant companies had failed to appeal against the decision of CARDINAL DATE on points of law under LAW ( f ) of LAW , whereas that remedy was available to any party who had been “ prevented from acting before a court as a result of the court ’s conduct ” .

On DATE the Government passed a resolution proposing that section CARDINAL of the Act be repealed , specifying in the explanatory report that this provision interfered with the insurance companies’ property in a discriminatory manner . The amendment was not adopted by the ORG , however .
In DATE a new LAW was adopted which maintained the applicant GPE obligation to pay PERCENT of the premiums collected .

Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) provided that insurance companies which did business in the field of compulsory contractual insurance of liability for damage caused by the operation of motor vehicles were obliged to pay to ORG , by DATE , PERCENT of the premiums for insurance in the abovementioned field collected in DATE . The insurance companies were obliged to report their fulfilment of this obligation to ORG within DATE .

Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) provided that ORG ( of the Interior ) , after consulting ORG , would pass on these funds to fire brigades , departments of ORG ( of the Interior ) , rescue services and emergency hotlines in order to meet the costs incurred in obtaining , maintaining and operating the material and facilities needed to research the causes of road accidents and to save and protect lives and property in road accidents .

In DATE a new LAW was adopted which replaced the relevant provisions of LAW . The obligation for the insurance companies to pay PERCENT of the premiums collected on a yearly basis was maintained in section CARDINAL of LAW . By DATE the Ministry ( of the Interior ) is required to inform ORG about the use made of the contributions paid by the insurance companies . ORG ( of the Interior ) is also under an obligation to make this information public .

Section CARDINAL imposes a duty to take out an insurance policy in respect of motor vehicles . With regard to domestic motor vehicles , this duty lies with the vehicle ’s holder , owner , operator or lessee ( sub - section CARDINAL ) . As to foreign motor vehicles , unless it is otherwise provided for , the person liable to arrange for the insurance of a vehicle is the vehicle ’s driver ( subsection CARDINAL ) . The duty to take out an insurance policy commences at the latest on DATE on which the motor vehicle is used ( sub - section CARDINAL ) .
